svg.title: Parfit's Repugnant Conclusion
svg.desc: A modified version of Parfit's diagram on p. 388 of his book "Reasons and Persons", showing how the Impersonal Total Principle (i.e., if other things are equal, the best outcome is the one in which there would be the greatest quantity of whatever makes life worth living) implies the Repugnant Conclusion.

cc:Work.dc:title: Parfit's Repugnant Conclusion
cc:Work.dc:description: A modified version of Parfit's diagram on p. 388 of his book "Reasons and Persons", showing how the Impersonal Total Principle (i.e., if other things are equal, the best outcome is the one in which there would be the greatest quantity of whatever makes life worth living) implies the Repugnant Conclusion.

rect.desc: Population of at least ten billion people, each with a very high quality of life
rect.title: Population Block A

rect.desc: Population with twice as many people as population A, but each with a lower quality of life than each of those in A
rect.title: Population Block B

rect.desc: Population with twice as many people as population B, but each with a lower quality of life than each of those in B
rect.title: Population Block C

path.desc: A divider between populations A and B
path.title: A-B Divider

path.desc: A divider between populations B and C
path.title: B-C Divider

path.desc: A divider between populations C and D (not shown).
path.title: C-Z Divider

text.title: Population A
text.tspan: A

text.title: Population B
text.tspan: B

text.title: Population C
text.tspan: C

text.title: Population Z
text.tspan: Z

path.desc: An arrow indicating the sequence of populations from D through Y (which are not shown).
path.title: Direction Arrow

text.desc: A statement of the Repugnant Conclusion which Parfit claims (on p. 388) is implied by the Impersonal Total Principle (i.e., if other things are equal, the best outcome is the one in which there would be the greatest quantity of whatever makes life worth living).
text.title: A statement of the Repugnant Conclusion
text.tspan: The Repugnant Conclusion: For any possible population of at least ten billion
people (such as A above), all with a very high quality of life, there must be some
much larger imaginable population (such as Z above) whose existence, if other
things are equal, would be better, even though its members have lives that are
barely worth living.

text.title: Parfit's Repugnant Conclusion
text.tspan: The Repugnant Conclusion

text.desc: Suggested by p. 388 in Derek Parfit's book, "Reasons and Persons," published by Oxford University Press in 1984.
text.title: Attribution
text.tspan: (from Parfit's Reasons and Persons, p. 388)

path.desc: The height of a block indicates the quality of life for each member of the population.
path.title: Direction Arrow

path.desc: The width of a block indicates the size of the population; C's population is twice the size of B's population.
path.title: Block Width for C

path.desc: The width of a block indicates the size of a population; B's population is twice the size of A's.
path.title: Block Width for B

path.desc: The width of a block indicates the size of a population; at at least ten billion, A has the smallest population.
path.title: Block Width for A

text.desc: Label for the direction arrow indicating the amount of whatever it is, perhaps happiness, that makes lives go well.
text.title: Quality of Life
text.tspan: Quality
of
Life

path.desc: The width of a block indicates the size of the population; Z has the largest population.
path.title: Block Width for Z

text.desc: The width of a block indicates the size of a population
text.title: Population Size Label
text.tspan: Size of Population

rect.title: Parfit's Repugnant Conclusion, showing how the Impersonal Total Principle implies a repugnant outcome having an enormous population with lives just barely worth living

text.tspan: A modified version of Parfit's diagram on p. 388 of his book
Reasons and Persons, showing how the Impersonal Total Principle
(i.e., if other things are equal, the best outcome is the one in
which there would be the greatest quantity of whatever makes life
worth living) implies the Repugnant Conclusion.
Population outcome A has a size of
ten billion people, and each person
has a very high quality of life.
Population outcome B is twice
the size of population A, but
each member's life has less
quality.
Population outcome C is twice the
size of population B, but each
member has a lower quality of life.
Population outcome Z is an enormously
large population, but each member has
only a life barely worth living.
